ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I deepened my skills in exegesis and philosophical assessment of historical texts.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is essentially a graduate seminar, so it's easy to see how the technical level of the discussion and emphasis on (somewhat arcane) debates in the secondary literature might put off those without much experience in ancient philosophy. But for those with more experience, the discussion could be enlightening and engaging. Nonetheless, there could have been some more effort to connect the interpretative debates to philosophical issues of broader interest.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend it to students with a clear interest in ancient Greek philosophy (Plato in particular). I'd suggest that those without such background might do better to pick a course that assumes less facility with the texts and secondary literature.
